title: 103_hr4759
content: The "Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Act of 1994" aims to enhance mathematics and science education by leveraging the Department of Energy's capabilities and fostering collaboration between federal agencies and educators. Recognizing the value of outstanding teachers, the Act proposes a program where these educators can contribute their expertise to education programs in government institutions. The "Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Act of 1994" establishes a national fellowship program for exceptional math and science teachers. Recipients of the fellowship are designated as "Albert Einstein Fellows." The Act defines terms such as "contractor" as a nonprofit educational organization selected by the Secretary, "Secretary" as the Secretary of Energy, "elementary school" and "local educational agency" as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, and "outstanding" for math or science teachers who have received specific recognitions. The Act defines terms related to education and recognizes outstanding math or science teachers who have received national or State recognition. Teachers must have participated in specific fellowship programs and received a sabbatical leave to qualify for the recognition. The Act authorizes a fellowship program for outstanding math or science teachers who have received national or State recognition. Teachers must have participated in specific fellowship programs and received a sabbatical leave to qualify for the recognition. The Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Program authorizes 10 fellowships for exceptional math or science teachers annually. The Secretary can reduce fellowship numbers based on funding availability, with priority given to selected individuals. The Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Program authorizes 10 fellowships annually for outstanding math or science teachers. The Secretary can prioritize selected individuals for fellowships in various government departments and agencies. The Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Program awards 10-month fellowships to outstanding math or science teachers. The program is administered by contractors who handle the application process and invite teachers from specific directories to apply. The Albert Einstein Fellowship Program administers fellowships to outstanding math and science teachers. The program includes the application process, publication in professional publications, initial screening of applicants, final selection of recipients, and orientation program for fellows. The Albert Einstein Fellowship Program administers fellowships to outstanding math and science teachers, including the development of selection processes, orientation programs for recipients, reporting and evaluation programs, annual reports to the Secretary, and fund administration. The Act covers expenses related to selecting outstanding math and science teachers for fellowships, including salaries, agreements with educational agencies, and fund disbursement. Funds can only be used for recipient salaries, insurance contributions, administrative expenses, orientation programs, relocation expenses, and final selection interviews. The contractor may seek additional funding. The contractor covers expenses for selecting math and science teachers for fellowships, including salaries, administrative costs, orientation programs, relocation expenses, and final selection interviews. The contractor can seek additional funding from non-Federal sources for travel and professional meeting expenses. Selected semifinalists are invited to Washington, D.C., for interviews, and final selections are announced before May 1 each year. The contractor is responsible for selecting fellowship recipients for the House of Representatives and the Senate, as well as various government agencies. Final selections are made before May 1 each year. Each selected fellowship recipient will be assigned within the department, agency, institute, or office of the selecting official. Final placement involves interviewing in different sections before the fellowship period begins. SEC. 6. Fellowship recipients will be paid at a rate not exceeding GS-13. SEC. 7. $550,000 authorized for 1995, with additional funds for 1996-2001.
